name=mhi_nuc_hist/>  ===2011 restart, controversy and reclosure===  in early 2011, units 2 and 3 were suspended for routine maintenance.

following the [[tohoku earthquake]], kyushu electric voluntarily sought reapproval with the town of genkai and saga prefecture to make sure that there would be no objection to turning the reactors back on.

negotiations extended several months past the normal restart time.<ref>http://mdn.mainichi.jp/mdnnews/news/20110608p2g00m0dm006000c.html</ref> because units 2 and 3 were not restarted for the summer, kyushu was expected to have an electricity shortage and only be able to meet 85% of normal summer needs.<ref>http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/05/19/nuclear-japan-kyushu-electric-idusl4e7gj0cv20110519</ref>
after the mayor of genkai extended his approval, the larger consensus of saga prefecture was sought.
a meeting was organized to inform the people in the district and to get permission to restart the reactors.
the meeting was broadcast live on tv and the internet, and viewers were invited to submit their opinions by e-mail or fax.

later, the [[japanese communist party]] paper  [[akahata]] learned that the board of the kyushu electric power company had requested employees of the plant to send emails to this meeting encouraging the restart.
later it was admitted that not only employees of the utility but the workers of 4 affiliated firms too, more than 1,500 people in total, received such requests.<ref>nhk-world

(8 july 2011) [http://www3.nhk.or.jp/daily/english/08_21.html systematic involvement suspected in genkai scandal]</ref>  at the same time as this crisis broke, prime minister [[naoto kan]] unexpectedly requested more stress tests of the reactor.

this seemed to imply, despite the earlier assurances of the national government, that the routine maintenance and additional post-earthquake tests had not been sufficient to clear the reactors for restart, and that the mayor of genkai had therefore approved the restart without complete information about the reactors safety.

as a result, the mayor rescinded his approval.<ref>[http://search.japantimes.co.jp/cgi-bin/nn20110707x1.html genkai mayor withdraws ok for two reactors restart]</ref> the governor of saga, who had not yet given his approval, also expressed surprise.<ref>[http://www.asahi.com/english/tky201107070243.html

genkai mayor retracts approval of reactor restarts after surprise stress tests]</ref> chief cabinet secretary [[yukio edano]] flew to saga prefecture immediately to apologize to the governor in person.<ref>[http://www.yomiuri.co.jp/dy/national/t110707005961.htm
mayor nixes genkai plant reactivation]</ref> on july 9, kan also apologized.<ref>[http://www.mcot.net/cfcustom/cache_page/235523.html

kan apologizes for confusion over restart of reactors]</ref>  on july 12, actor [[taro yamamoto]], a tokyo resident who had flown into saga to protest the potential restart, broke into the offices of saga prefecture trying to force the governor to come out. he was unsuccessful but proclaimed that he was glad he had come to protest.<ref>[http://www.nikkansports.com/entertainment/news/p-et-tp0-20110712-803766.html
山本太郎　佐賀県庁突入「知事出てこい」]</ref>  on 2 november 2011 the no. 4 reactor, the newest model, was restarted.
the reactor was the first in japan to resume operations after the march accident at fukushima daiichi nuclear plant.
in december the reactor was stopped again for a regular inspection.<ref>nhk-world

(2 november 2011) [http://www3.nhk.or.jp/daily/english/02_33.html genkai reactor resumes power generation]</ref><ref>jaif (2 november 2011) [http://www.jaif.or.jp/english/news_images/pdf/engnews01_1320208900p.pdf

earthquake-report 253 ]</ref>  on 9 december 2011 a leak was discovered in the cooling system of reactor no. 3. an alarm was triggered when the temperature rose to over 80c at the base of one of the pumps, but this alarm did not indicate the leakage of 1.8 cubic meters of radioactive water, because the water did not go outside the purification system.
after the leak was discovered kyushu electric failed to report the troubles in full to the local government.
only the failure of the pumps in the system for the no. 3 reactor were mentioned.<ref>the
daily mainichi news (10 december 2011)[http://mdn.mainichi.jp/mdnnews/news/20111209p2g00m0dm181000c.html

radioactive water leaks at kyushu electrics genkai reactor]</ref>  as of september 2012, saga prefecture was aiming to have the genkai reactors permanently retired after 40 years of operation, meaning that reactor 1 would close in 2015.<ref>[http://kyushu.yomiuri.co.jp/news/national/20120920-oys1t00221.htm

佐賀知事が廃炉容認、玄海１号機運転４０年で]</ref> a citizens group sued to have the reactors shut down immediately, but the state argued that there is no process in japanese law that could cause an industrys operations to cease through a civil, rather than criminal, action.<ref>[http://www.saga-s.co.jp/news/saga.0.2291675.article.html
「史上最悪の公害事件」　玄海原発操業停止訴訟 ]</ref> as of april 2016, the plant remains shut down.

the plant, like all other nuclear power plants in japan, did not generate electricity since the nationwide shutdown in the wake of the [[fukushima daiichi nuclear disaster]] in 2011, but was restarted on august 11, 2015, and began providing power to nearby towns again.
sendai is the first of japans nuclear power plants to be restarted.
the reports were sent to the japanese [[nuclear and industrial safety agency]].

the {{nihongo|sendai nuclear power plant|川内原子力発電所|sendai genshiryoku hatsudensho|sendai npp}} is a [[nuclear power plant]] located in the city of [[satsumasendai, kagoshima|satsumasendai]] in [[kagoshima prefecture]].
it is owned and operated by the [[kyūshū electric power company]].

the plant, like all other nuclear power plants in japan, did not generate electricity since the nationwide shutdown in the wake of the [[fukushima daiichi nuclear disaster]] in 2011, but was restarted on august 11, 2015, and began providing power to nearby towns again.
sendai is the first of japans nuclear power plants to be restarted.

the plant is on a site of 1.45 km<sup>2</sup> (358 acres), employs 277 workers, and indirectly employs 790.  the reactors are of the 3-loop m type [[pressurized water reactor]], built by [[mitsubishi heavy industries]].<ref
name=iaea-table2>{{cite web |url=http://www-pub.iaea.org/mtcd/publications/pdf/cnpp2010_cd/pages/annexii/tables/table2.htm|
title=reactors in operation |date=december 31, 2009 |publisher=[[iaea]] |accessdate=march 12, 2011}}</ref>  ==reactors on site== {| class=wikitable !
name ! reactor type !
commission date !
gross power rating !
core tonnage !

price to build |- | sendai-1 | [[pressurized water reactor|pwr]] | july 4, 1984 | 890 mw | 72 tons/[[uranium dioxide]] | 278.7 billion yen |- | sendai-2 | [[pressurized water reactor|pwr]] | november 28, 1985 | 890 mw | 72 tons/[[uranium dioxide]] | 228.7 billion yen |}  ==stress-tests published in 2011-restart crises == on 14 december 2011 the kyushu electric power company published the outcome of the primary safety assessments or stress-tests for three of its suspended nuclear reactors: two of them located at the sendai nuclear power plant in  [[kagoshima]] prefecture, the third at was located the [[genkai nuclear power plant]] in [[saga]] prefecture.
the reports were sent to the japanese [[nuclear and industrial safety agency]].
the papers were also sent to the local authorities of the prefectures where the plants were located, because the reactors are not allowed to be restarted without their consent.
according  to the test, the reactors could withstand a seismic shock of 945 to 1,020 gals <!-- what does that mean ??? --> and tsunami-waves of a height of 13 to 15 meters.

the power company asked its customers to reduce their power-consumption by at least 5% after 26 december, because at 25 december the number 4 reactor in genkai would be taken out of operation for regular check-ups.
nuclear power generation did account for about 40 percent of the total output of the company, according to company official akira nakamura.
he said that restarting reactors was crucial for them, and that the company will do all it can do to win back public-trust.

however, hideo kishimoto, the mayor of genkai said that it would be difficult to resume operations. he asked kyushu electric to disclose their practices in full, besides their efforts to prevent future accidents.<ref>jaif
(14 december 2011)[http://www.jaif.or.jp/english/news_images/pdf/engnews01_1323921629p.pdf

earthquake-report 291: kyushu electric submits test results of 3 reactors]</ref>  ==draft safety test report 2013-2014== according to a special bulletin<ref name=koyama>{{cite web  | url = https://eneken.ieej.or.jp/data/5582.pdf

| title = sendai nuclear plant effectively passes safety tests toward restarting in autumn  | last = koyama  | first = ken  | date = july 17, 2014  | publisher = the institute of energy economics, japan  | access-date = may 16, 2016}}</ref> issued on july 17, 2014 by the institute of energy economics, japan, in june 2013 the japanese [[nuclear regulation authority]] (nra) created new stricter safety standards for all japanese nuclear power plants.
tests on 19 reactors at 12 nuclear power plants based on the new standards began the following month and were expected to take six months, but took longer on account of their strictness.
the two-reactor sendai plant was given priority and was approved by the nra as meeting both its earthquake and tsunami assumptions in march 2014.

an effective safety test pass certificate was issued on july 16 and the draft safety test report was opened to public comments until august 15.  the basis for the approval was enhanced safety measures, in particular raising the previous assumption for the sendai plant of 540 gal for maximum earthquake strength to 620 gal, and similarly the assumption of maximum tsunami height from 4 meters to 5 meters.
furthermore, a 10-meter-high protection wall was built.
design standards were further enhanced to take into account all other natural disasters, in particular volcanic eruptions and tornadoes, along with plans to address terrorist attacks.
further details on the tests may be found in the special bulletin.<ref
name=koyama/>  == restarting ==  on 10 september 2014 the nra declared that the plant was safe to be operated.

actual operation was originally expected by the end of 2014, following approval of local authorities,<ref> {{cite news  | last = fackler  | first = martin  | date = 11 sep 2014  | title = three years after fukushima, japan approves a nuclear plant  | url = http://www.nytimes.com/2014/09/11/world/asia/japanese-nuclear-plant-declared-safe-to-operate-for-first-time-since-fukushima-daiichi-disaster.html?ref=world  | newspaper = new york times  | location = new york  | accessdate = 11 sep 2014 }} </ref> however, local and national groups and [[ngo]]s opposed the planned restart of the sendai nuclear plants.

[[john large]] of the london-based consulting engineers large & associates], provided opinion and evidence in an ongoing civil action in japan contesting the restart of the sendai nuclear power plant<ref name=comparison of nra and iaea volcanic evaluation guides> {{cite news  | url = https://www.greenpeace.de/sites/www.greenpeace.de/files/publications/r3229-e1-john-large-atomkraft-japan-20150128.pdf

| title = the assessment guide of volcanic effects of nuclear power plants compared with the international atomic energy agencys volcanic hazards evaluation for nuclear installations, ssg-21, 2012  | date = 28 january 2015  | publisher = greenpeace germany  | accessdate = 28 january 2015 }} </ref> and separately large & associates prepared an assessment of the effectiveness of the japanese nra recently introduced guide for the evaluation of nuclear power plant sites with respect to the potential affects of volcanic effects, specifically aligning this to the sendai npp presently proposed for restart following a four-year shut down in the aftermath of [[fukushima daiichi]].<ref
name=implications of tephra ash fall on sendai npp> {{cite news  | url = http://www.greenpeace.org/japan/global/japan/pdf/volcano_ash_report_by_john_large.pdf

| title = implications of tephra ash fall out on the operational safety of sendai nuclear power plants  | date = 26 february 2015  | publisher = greenpeace germany  | accessdate = 26 february 2015 }} </ref>  in april 2015, a japanese court rejected a complaint against the restart.<ref
name=apan court approves restart of reactors> {{cite news  | url = http://www.reuters.com/article/2015/04/22/us-japan-nuclear-courts-iduskbn0nc1qd20150422

| title = japan court approves restart of reactors in boost for abes nuclear policy  | date = 22 april 2015  | publisher = reuters  | accessdate = 7 may 2015 }} </ref> on may 28, 2015, the nuclear regulation authority approved the station’s emergency plans, which was the last regulatory hurdle remaining before restarts could happen.
owner kyushu electric power company then had all approvals necessary for restart.<ref>
http://www.hiroshimasyndrome.com/fukushima-86.html
</ref> on july 7, 2015, fuel loading of sendai unit #1 began.
the nra completed its pre-operational examinations and gave kyushu electric company the green light to place fuel inside the reactor vessel.<ref>
http://jen.jiji.com/jc/eng?g=eco&k=2015070700170
</ref><ref> http://www.japantimes.co.jp /news/2015/07/07/national/fuel-loaded-kagoshima-reactor-first-restart-nears/#.vzu2vamw8du</ref>
sendais reactor no. 1 was restarted on august 11, 2015.<ref>kyushu

electric homepage:[http://www.kyuden.co.jp/en_press_150810-1.html?media=smart press release] 10 august 2015</ref><ref>[http://www.kyuden.co.jp/en_information_150811.html startup of sendai nuclear power unit no.1] (11 august 2015)</ref> [[naoto kan]], former [[prime minister of japan|prime minister]] (2010-2011), was among the protesters who were demonstrating in front of the sendai plant when the reactor was restarted.<ref>{{cite

web|title=japan restarts first nuclear power plant since fukushima|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-33858350|website=bbc news|publisher=bbc|accessdate=11 august 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=japan restarts first nuclear reactor since fukushima disaster|url=http://www.theguardian.com/environment/2015/aug/11/japan-restarts-first-nuclear-reactor-fukushima-disaster|website=the

guardian|accessdate=11 august 2015}}</ref>  on november 1, 2015, followed reactor n.2, at full-capacity the same day, with its thermal output reaching the maximum level, about two weeks after it was reactivated.
no major problems occurred in the process.
the utility first restarted reactor n.2, removing the control rods on october, 15.<ref>{{cite news  | url = http://the-japan-news.com/news/article/0002534317

| title = sendai no. 2 reactor in full-capacity operation  | date = 1 november 2015  | publisher = japan news (the yomiuri shimbun)  | accessdate = 7 november 2015 }}</ref>  ==references== {{reflist}}  ==external links== {{commons category|sendai nuclear power plant}} *[http://www.kyuden.co.jp/ kyushu electric webpage 九州電力] {{ja}} *[http://www.kyuden.co.jp/sendai_index sendai npp c/o kyushu electric 九州電力・川内原子力発電所] {{ja}}  {{nuclear power in japan}}  [[category:buildings and structures in kagoshima prefecture]] [[category:nuclear power stations in japan]] [[category:1970s establishments in japan]] [[category:nuclear power stations using pressurized water reactors]]

the plant is owned and operated by [[endesa (spain)|endesa]].<ref
name=rew060707/><ref name=rew260908/>  in 2007, endesa received a municipal permit to build a 20.1 megawatt (mw) photovoltaic solar power plant.<ref
name=rew060707/>  construction on the first stage of the plant began in july 2007 and was finished in september 2008.<ref
name=rew060707/><ref name=ro220908>{{cite news  | url= http://www.redorbit.com/news/business/1563399/endesa_inaugurates_guadarranque_solar_energy_plant/
| title= endesa inaugurates guadarranque solar energy plant  | work= datamonitor  | publisher = redorbit, inc.
| date=2008-09-22  | accessdate=2010-12-25}} </ref>  the first stage has installed capacity of 12.3 mw and it covers {{convert|37|ha}}.<ref
name=rew060707>{{cite news  | url= http://www.renewableenergyworld.com/rea/news/article/2007/07/endesa-to-build-20-1mw-solar-energy-plant-in-spain-49241

{{redirect|segs|the airport with that icao code|seymour airport}}  {{geogrouptemplate}} solar energy generating systems (segs) in [[california]], with the combined capacity from three separate locations at 354 [[megawatts]] (mw, 474,700 hp), is now the worlds [[list of solar thermal power stations#operational|second largest]] [[solar thermal energy]] generating facility, after the commissioning of the even larger [[ivanpah solar power facility|ivanpah facility]] in 2014. it consists of nine [[solar power plant]]s in californias [[mojave desert]], where [[insolation]] is among the best available in the united states.

segs i–ii (44 mw) are located at [[daggett, california|daggett]] ({{coord|34|51|45|n|116|49|45|w}}), segs iii–vii (150 mw) are installed at [[kramer junction, california|kramer junction]] ({{coord|35|00|43|n|117|33|32|w}}), and segs viii–ix (160 mw) are placed at [[harper lake]] ({{coord|35|01|55|n|117|20|50|w}}).<ref

name=energy_blog_2005_09>[http://thefraserdomain.typepad.com/energy/2005/09/about_parabolic.html the energy blog: about parabolic trough solar<!-- bot generated title -->]</ref> [[nextera energy resources]] operates and partially owns the plants located at kramer junction and harper lake.

a tenth plant (segs x, 80 mw) had been in construction and segs xi and segs xii had been planned by [[brightsource energy|luz industries]], but the developer filed for bankruptcy in 1992, because it was unable to secure construction financing.<ref

name=cec_filing>{{cite web |url=http://www.energy.ca.gov/sitingcases/solar/ |title=large solar energy projects |publisher = california energy commission  | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20160714141020/http://www.energy.ca.gov/sitingcases/solar/  | archive-date = 14 july 2016  | dead-url = no |accessdate=14 july 2016}}</ref>  ==plants scale and operations== the plants have a 354 mw net (394 mw gross) installed capacity. the nameplate capacity, which operating continuously, would dеliver the samе net power output, coming only from the solar source is around {{nowrap|75 [[mwe]] —}}, representing a 21% [[capacity factor]].
in addition, the turbines can be utilized at night by burning [[natural gas]].

nextera claims that the solar plants power 232,500 homеs (during the day, at peak power) and displace 3,800 tons of pollution pеr year that would have been produced if the electricity had bееn providеd by fossil fuels, such as oil.<ref
name=fpl energy solar factsheet>{{cite web |url=http://www.nexteraenergyresources.com/content/where/portfolio/pdf/segs.pdf
|format=pdf |title=solar electric generating system |accessdate=2009-12-13 }}</ref>  the facilities have a total of 936,384 mirrors and cover more than {{convert|1600|acre|ha|1}}.

lined up, the parabolic mirrors would extend over {{convert|229|mi|km|0}}.  as an example of cost, in 2002, one of the 30 mw kramer junction sites required $90 million to construct, and its operation and maintenance cost was about $3 million per year (4.6 cents per kilowatt hour).<ref>reducing the cost of energy from parabolic trough solar power plants, nrel, 2003</ref> with a considered lifetime of 20 years, the operation, maintenance and investments interest and depreciation triples the price, to approximately 14 cents per kilowatt hour.{{citation

needed|date=june 2013}}  ==principle of operation== [[image:parabolic trough.svg|thumb|left|upright|sketch of a parabolic trough collector]] the installation uses [[parabolic trough]], [[solar thermal]] technology along with [[natural gas]] to generate [[electricity]].
about 90% of the electricity is produced by the [[sunlight]].{{citation
needed|date=june 2013}} natural gas is only used when the solar power is insufficient to meet the demand from [[southern california edison]], the distributor of power in southern california.
Erro:510
the greatest source of mirror breakage is wind, with 3,000 mirrors typically replaced each year.
operators can turn the mirrors to protect them during intense wind storms.
an automated washing mechanism is used to periodically clean the parabolic reflective panels.
Erro:507
the synthetic oil transfers its heat to water, which boils and drives the [[rankine cycle]] steam turbine,<ref name=solel>{{cite web |url=http://www.solel.com/products/pgeneration/ls2/

|title=solar thermal power generation | publisher = solel solar systems ltd |accessdate=2010-09-30 |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080601185224/http://www.solel.com/products/pgeneration/ls2/
synthetic oil is used to carry the heat (instead of water) to keep the pressure within manageable parameters.

name=cec_filing/>  kramer junction employs about 95 people and 45 people work at harper lake.

16,512,534 |}  === harper lake === segs viii and segs ix, located at  {{coord|35.031815|-117.347270

|format=dms |region:us-ca_type:landmark |name=segs viii and ix}}, until [[ivanpah solar power facility]] commissioning in 2014, were the largest solar thermal power plants individually and collectively in the world.<ref>jones,
j. (2000), [http://www.osti.gov/accomplishments/documents/fulltext/acc0196.pdf
solar trough power plants], [[national renewable energy laboratory]].
they were the last, the largest, and the most advanced of the nine plants at segs, designed to take advantage of the economies of scale.
construction of the tenth plant in the same locality was halted because of the bankruptcy of luz industries.
construction of the approved eleventh and twelfth plants never started.

each of the three planned plants had 80 mw of installed capacity.<ref>[http://www.energy.ca.gov/siting/solar/index.html california energy commission - large solar energy projects]</ref> [[abengoa solar]] recently constructed the 280mw [[mojave solar project]] (msp) adjacent to the segs viii and segs ix plants.<ref>[http://www.abengoasolar.com/web/en/plantas_solares/plantas_para_terceros/estados_unidos/index.html
abengoa solar - the mojave solar project]</ref> the msp also uses concentrating solar thermal trough technology.

reflectors at kramer junction site facing the western sky to focus the late afternoon sunlight at the absorber tubes partially seen in the picture as bright white spots.]]

angra nuclear power plant is one of brazils few nuclear power plants.

it is located at the central nuclear almirante álvaro alberto (cnaaa) on the itaorna beach in [[angra dos reis]], [[rio de janeiro (state)|rio de janeiro]], [[brazil]]. it consists of two [[pressurized water reactor]]s, angra i, with a net output of 637 [[mwe#electrical and thermal watts|mwe]],<ref>[http://www.eletronuclear.gov.br/aempresa/centralnuclear/informa%c3%a7%c3%b5esangra1.aspx

national report of brazil, nuclear installations|accessdate=2015-04-24}}</ref> and angra ii, with a net output of 1,350 mwe,<ref>[http://www.eletronuclear.gov.br/aempresa/centralnuclear/informa%c3%a7%c3%b5esangra2.aspx

power reactor information system] of the [[international atomic energy agency|iaea]]: [http://www.iaea.org/cgi-bin/db.page.pl/pris.powrea.htm?country=br&sort=&sortlong=alphabetic brazil, federative republic of : nuclear power reactors]</ref><ref name=eletronuclear>[http://www.eletronuclear.gov.br/not%c3%adcias/noticiadetalhes.aspx?noticiaid=1446 eletronuclear - obras civis de angra 3 voltarão ao ritmo normal]</ref>  ==existing complex== the central nuclear almirante álvaro alberto complex is administrated by [[eletronuclear]], a state company with the [[monopoly]] in nuclear power generation in brazil.
as a result, angra ii was built with german technology, as part of a comprehensive nuclear agreement between brazil and [[west germany]] signed by president [[ernesto geisel]] in 1975.

angra nuclear power plant is one of brazils few nuclear power plants.

it is located at the central nuclear almirante álvaro alberto (cnaaa) on the itaorna beach in [[angra dos reis]], [[rio de janeiro (state)|rio de janeiro]], [[brazil]]. it consists of two [[pressurized water reactor]]s, angra i, with a net output of 637 [[mwe#electrical and thermal watts|mwe]],<ref>[http://www.eletronuclear.gov.br/aempresa/centralnuclear/informa%c3%a7%c3%b5esangra1.aspx

national report of brazil, nuclear installations|accessdate=2015-04-24}}</ref> and angra ii, with a net output of 1,350 mwe,<ref>[http://www.eletronuclear.gov.br/aempresa/centralnuclear/informa%c3%a7%c3%b5esangra2.aspx

power reactor information system] of the [[international atomic energy agency|iaea]]: [http://www.iaea.org/cgi-bin/db.page.pl/pris.powrea.htm?country=br&sort=&sortlong=alphabetic brazil, federative republic of : nuclear power reactors]</ref><ref name=eletronuclear>[http://www.eletronuclear.gov.br/not%c3%adcias/noticiadetalhes.aspx?noticiaid=1446 eletronuclear - obras civis de angra 3 voltarão ao ritmo normal]</ref>  ==existing complex== the central nuclear almirante álvaro alberto complex is administrated by [[eletronuclear]], a state company with the [[monopoly]] in nuclear power generation in brazil.

the complex employs some 3,000 people and generates another 10,000 indirect jobs in [[rio de janeiro (state)|rio de janeiro state]].

angra i was purchased from [[westinghouse electric corporation (1886)|westinghouse]] of the [[united states|usa]] (its sister power plant is [[krško nuclear power plant]] in slovenia<ref>http://entrac.iaea.org/i-and-c/tm_prague_2007_05/cd/papers/furieri_paper.pdf</ref>).
the complex was designed to have three [[pressurized water reactor|pwr]] units with a total output of around 3,000 mwe and was to be the first of 4 nuclear plants that would be built up to 1990.

president approved the construction in july 2007. in december 2008, eletronuclear signed an industrial cooperation agreement with [[areva]].

the ignalina nuclear power plant ({{lang-lt|ignalinos atominė elektrinė, iae}}, {{lang-ru|игналинская атомная электростанция, ignalinskaya atomnaya elektrostantsiya}}) is a closed two-unit [[rbmk]]-1500 [[nuclear power plant|nuclear power station]] in [[visaginas municipality]], [[lithuania]]. it was named after the nearby city of [[ignalina]].
1.]]  the ignalina nuclear power plant contained two [[rbmk]]-1500 [[water-cooled]] [[graphite]]-[[neutron moderator|moderated]] channel-type power [[nuclear reactor|reactors]].

name=td3>{{cite web|url=http://www.iae.lt/en/about-us/history/technical-data/?page=3|title=ignalina nuclear power plant: technical data|accessdate=2015-12-11}}</ref>  in december 1983, when ignalina unit 1 came online, a design flaw of the [[rbmk]] was noticed for the first time.

web|url=http://cat.inist.fr/?amodele=affichen&cpsidt=18041752|title=radiological and thermal characteristics of castor rbmk-1500 and constor rbmk-1500 casks for spent nuclear fuel storage at ignalina nuclear power plant|publisher=[[hanser]], cited through cat.inist|year=2006| accessdate=2010-01-01}}</ref>  in 2005, lithuanian authorities told that russian agent [[vladimir alganov]]—earlier deported from poland—had been granted a lithuanian visa for some reason and he had met managers of ignalina in 2003.<ref>{{cite

| date=january 2005 | accessdate = 2009-10-17}}</ref>  ==incidents== according to an ignalina nuclear power plant press release, on june 6, 2009, at 09:15 eest (06:15 utc), the automatic reactor protection system was actuated and unit 2 was shut down.

press release | title = inpp preventive maintenance | publisher = ignalina nuclear power plant | date = 6 june 2009 | url = http://www.iae.lt/infocenter_en.asp?lang=1&note=6&sub=111&newsparam=1611&year=2009 | accessdate = 31 december 2009}}</ref>  ==shutdown== [[file:rbmk reactor from ignalina arm.jpg|thumb|right|ignalina

| publisher = [[european commission]] | title = faq on ignalina nuclear power plant for public affairs | accessdate = 1 july 2009}}</ref> the [[european union]] agreed to pay €820 million [[nuclear decommissioning|decommissioning]] costs and compensation,<ref name=bbc/> with payments continuing until 2013.

| title = lithuania picks hitachi ge for nuclear plant plan  | agency = [[reuters]]  | date=2011-07-14  | accessdate=2011-07-14}} </ref>  ==see also== *[[energy in lithuania]]  ==references== {{reflist|2}}  ==external links== {{commons category|ignalina nuclear power plant}} *[http://www.iae.lt/default_en.asp?lang=1&subsub=10001 official website] *[http://www.visaginas.narod.ru/photos/history_iae/index.html the history of ignalina nuclear power plant construction in pictures]  [[category:former nuclear power stations in lithuania]] [[category:nuclear power stations using rbmk reactors]] [[category:nuclear power stations with closed reactors]] [[category:power stations in visaginas]] [[category:buildings and structures in utena county]] [[category:nuclear power stations built in the soviet union]]

the ignalina nuclear power plant ({{lang-lt|ignalinos atominė elektrinė, iae}}, {{lang-ru|игналинская атомная электростанция, ignalinskaya atomnaya elektrostantsiya}}) is a closed two-unit [[rbmk]]-1500 [[nuclear power plant|nuclear power station]] in [[visaginas municipality]], [[lithuania]]. it was named after the nearby city of [[ignalina]].

due to the plants similarities to the failed [[chernobyl nuclear power plant]] in both reactor design and lack of a robust [[containment building]],<ref>{{cite book|title=transboundary risk management|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=aem1gmpgqk0c&pg=pa35|page= 35 |last1= linnerooth-bayer |first1= joanne |last2= [[ragnar löfstedt|löfstedt]] |first2= [[ragnar löfstedt|ragnar]] |last3= sjöstedt |first3= gunnar|publisher=[[earthscan]]|year=2001|isbn= 978-1-85383-537-7|accessdate=31 december 2009}}</ref> lithuania agreed to close the plant as part of its accession agreement to the [[european union]].

the remaining unit 2 which counted for 25%<!--deutcshe welle says 40%: ...and accounts for about 40 percent of the countrys overall production capacity.--> of lithuanias electricity generating capacity and supplied about 70% of lithuanias electrical demand,<ref name=dw311209a>{{cite news | title = lithuania shuts down last reactor | url = http://www.dw-world.de/dw/article/0,,5074094,00.html
name=bbc>{{cite news | title = lithuania to shut its only nuclear power station | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/8435628.stm

| publisher = bbc news | date = 31 december 2009 |accessdate=31 december 2009}}</ref><ref name=businessweek>{{cite news | title =lithuania shuts down soviet-built nuclear reactor | url = http://www.businessweek.com/ap/financialnews/d9cucpio0.htm

| publisher = [[bloomberg l.p.|bloomberg]]| author = dapkus, liudas | work = [[businessweek]]| date = 31 december 2009 |accessdate=31 december 2009}}</ref><ref name=reuters311209a>{{cite news | title = lithuania to shut soviet-era nuclear plant | url = http://uk.reuters.com/article/iduklde5bu0ic20091231?sp=true | publisher = reuters| author = adomaitis, nerijus | date = 31 december 2009 |accessdate=31 december 2009}}</ref>  originally, unit 2 was scheduled for launch in 1986, but its commissioning was postponed for a year because of the [[chernobyl accident]].
it was sited next to the largest lake in lithuania, [[lake drūkšiai]] (part of which lies in neighbouring [[belarus]]) which provided the plants cooling water.

web|title=evaluation of ignalina npp waste waters toxicity by use of biotest complex| publisher=institute of botany, vilnius (lithuania) ([[lithuanian academy of sciences]])|year=1995| url=http://md1.csa.com/partners/viewrecord.php?requester=gs&collection=env&recid=4050181&q=ignalina+lake+druksiai&uid=788819292&setcookie=yes|accessdate=2010-01-01}}</ref>  its [[spent fuel]] was placed in castor and constor [[dry cask storage|storage casks]] during the 2000s.<ref>{{cite

web|url=http://cat.inist.fr/?amodele=affichen&cpsidt=18041752|title=radiological and thermal characteristics of castor rbmk-1500 and constor rbmk-1500 casks for spent nuclear fuel storage at ignalina nuclear power plant|publisher=[[hanser]], cited through cat.inist|year=2006| accessdate=2010-01-01}}</ref>  in 2005, lithuanian authorities told that russian agent [[vladimir alganov]]—earlier deported from poland—had been granted a lithuanian visa for some reason and he had met managers of ignalina in 2003.<ref>{{cite

rbmk reactor tube tops]] [[file:ignalina kerncentrale 4.jpg|thumb|right|info about shutdown]]  as a condition of entry into the [[european union]], lithuania agreed in 1999 to close existing units of the station, citing the ignalina plants lack of a [[containment building]] as a high risk.<ref>{{cite
closure of the plant faced fierce opposition from the lithuanian people.

journal|title=a plan of measures for the economic and social restructuring of the ignalina nuclear power plant region|publisher=lithuanian regional research institute|url=http://www.lrti.lt/english/activities/projects/ignalinaae_research.doc|accessdate= 9 december 2009}}</ref> others were afraid that the price of electricity would skyrocket or that lithuania would be left to cope with the extremely high costs of decommissioning the plant and disposing of its [[nuclear waste]].

a [[lithuanian nuclear power referendum, 2008|2008 referendum]] proposed extending the operation of unit 2 until a new nuclear plant could be completed as a replacement; the referendum gained 1,155,192 votes for the proposal, but ultimately failed to gain the 50% turnout necessary to be passed.<ref>{{cite

rinkimai į lietuvos respublikos seimą ir referendumas dėl ignalinos atominės elektrinės darbo pratęsimo| publisher=[[republic of lithuania]]|url=http://www.vrk.lt/2008_seimo_rinkimai/output_lt/referendumas/referendumas.html|accessdate=2008-12-11|
language = lithuanian}}</ref> president [[valdas adamkus]] opposed the measure on grounds that continued operation would not respect lithuanias international commitments.<ref>{{cite

18 september 2008|accessdate= 11 december 2008}}</ref>  the lithuanian government forecasts that the electricity price for households will rise by 30% from 2010.<ref name=reuters311209a/><ref name=telegraph291209>{{cite news | publisher= telegraph media group limited | title = lithuania power crisis looms as nuclear plant shuts  | url= http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/lithuania/6904781/lithuania-power-crisis-looms-as-nuclear-plant-shuts.html

| author = day, matthew | work = telegraph.co.uk | date = 29 december 2009 | accessdate= 31 december 2009}}</ref> analysts expect that the shutdown could cut lithuanias [[gross domestic product]] growth by 1–1.5%, and increase inflation by 1%.<ref name= reuters311209a/> ignalinas production will be compensated for by production of the [[fossil fuel]] [[elektrėnai power plant]] as well as by imports from russia, [[latvia]], [[estonia]], [[ukraine]], and [[belarus]].<ref

name=reuters311209a/><ref name=bloomberg311209a>{{cite news | title = lithuania prepared to shut nuclear plant today, premier says | url = http://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=newsarchive&sid=av6xj4vawlos

| publisher = [[bloomberg l.p.|bloomberg]] | author = seputyte, milda | date = 31 december 2009 | accessdate=31 december 2009}}</ref> the closure may test [[lithuania-russia relations|lithuanian-russian relations]].<ref
title = lithuania nuclear shutdown to test eu-russia relations| url = http://euobserver.com/9/29209|

author = rettman, andrew | date = 31 december 2009| accessdate = 1 january 2010}}</ref> responding to concerns that lithuania would become more dependent on russian energy sources that could be withdrawn if relations deteriorate, president [[dalia grybauskaitė]] issued reassuring statements in late 2009.<ref

name=euobserver29209/> lithuania imports 70% of its power from belarus, and the average price of electricity is among the highest in eu.<ref>[http://ec.europa.eu/eurostat/statistics-explained/index.php/electricity_and_natural_gas_price_statistics

current electricity flows]</ref><ref>http://www.institutdelors.eu/media/balticstateseu-energypolicy-grigas-ne-jdi-july13.pdf?pdf=ok</ref> in 2015, transmission lines connected lithuania to [[nordbalt|sweden (700mw)]] and [[litpol link|poland (500mw)]].<ref>http://www.forbes.com/sites/williampentland/2015/12/13/electric-transmission-lines-are-about-to-undercut-russias-influence-in-baltic-region/?utm_source=dlvr.it&utm_medium=twitter</ref>

by 2030, the site of two reactors should be ready for re-use ([[brownfield land|brownfield]]).<ref name=eer080911> {{cite news  | url= http://www.europeanenergyreview.eu/site/pagina.php?id=3200  | title= lithuania on collision course with ebrd over dismantling of ignalina  | first = reiner | last = gatermann  | date= 2011-09-08  | work= world nuclear news  | accessdate= 2011-09-09}} </ref>  on 26 november 2002, lithuanian government passed a resolution to the effect that the ignalina npp unit 1 is to be decommissioned through immediate dismantling.

name=wnn040210> {{cite news  | url= http://www.world-nuclear-news.org/newsarticle.aspx?id=29371  | title= defueling underway at ignalina 2  | date= 2010-02-04  | work= world nuclear news  | accessdate= 2011-09-08}} </ref>  ===financing=== the decommissioning program has been financed from the european union, ignalina international decommissioning support fund, se ignalina npp national decommissioning fund, and targeted specific grants from lithuanian [[state budget]] for [[municipalities]].{{citation
needed|date=september 2011}}  about 95% of the funds  have been provided by the international community, while 5% is provided by lithuanian state.<ref
name=wnn160210> {{cite news  | url= http://www.world-nuclear-news.org/wr-decommissioning_underway_in_lithuania-1602101.html

| title= decommissioning underway in lithuania  | first = monika | last = hanley  | date= 2010-02-16  | work= world nuclear news  | accessdate= 2011-09-08}} </ref>  on 20–21 june 2000, the international donors conference for decommissioning projects of unit 1 took place in lithuania.

name=eer080911/><ref>{{cite news|title=eu grants eur 50 mln for upgrading of lithuanian power plant|url=http://www.euro.lt/en/news/lithuanias-membership-in-the-eu/news/2323/|publisher=lithuania in the european union| agency = [[baltic news service|bns]]|date=2007-12-20|accessdate=2008-04-29}}</ref>  in order to ensure proper funding of decommissioning until 2029, €1.48 billion additional support from the eu is needed, of which: * €870 million for the period from 2014 to 2020.{{citation needed|date=september 2011}} * €610 million for the period from 2021 to 2029.{{citation needed|date=september 2011}}  lithuanias national contribution to the financing of decommissioning process from 1999 to 2029 will compose about €320 million (12%): *€182 million is planned for the period until 2014.{{citation

on february 27, 2006, at a meeting in [[trakai]], the prime ministers of lithuania, latvia and estonia signed a communiqué which invited state-owned energy companies in lithuania, latvia and estonia to invest in the design and construction of a new nuclear power plant in lithuania.<ref
| accessdate = 31 july 2008}}</ref> on june 28, 2007, lithuanias parliament adopted a law on building a new nuclear power plant, the formal start of a project.<ref>{{cite

|title = lithuania adopts law on new nuclear power plant |publisher = reuters |date=28 june 2008 |accessdate=9 july 2008}}</ref> on july 30, 2008, the power companies of lithuania, estonia, latvia, and poland agreed to set up the visaginas nuclear plant company, which will be responsible for the construction of the new power plant with a capacity of 3,000–3,200 mw.<ref name=wnn1>{{cite news | url = http://www.world-nuclear-news.com/newsarticle.aspx?id=19138 | title = visaginas recognised with nuclear site name | publisher = world nuclear news | date=30 july 2008 | accessdate=31 july 2008}}</ref>  [[ge hitachi nuclear energy]] is selected as a strategic investor of the project.<ref

needed|date=october 2014}} after the [[chernobyl disaster]] of april 1986 the reactor was de-rated to 1,360 mw.

the ignalina nuclear power plant ({{lang-lt|ignalinos atominė elektrinė, iae}}, {{lang-ru|игналинская атомная электростанция, ignalinskaya atomnaya elektrostantsiya}}) is a closed two-unit [[rbmk]]-1500 [[nuclear power plant|nuclear power station]] in [[visaginas municipality]], [[lithuania]]. it was named after the nearby city of [[ignalina]].

due to the plants similarities to the failed [[chernobyl nuclear power plant]] in both reactor design and lack of a robust [[containment building]],<ref>{{cite book|title=transboundary risk management|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=aem1gmpgqk0c&pg=pa35|page= 35 |last1= linnerooth-bayer |first1= joanne |last2= [[ragnar löfstedt|löfstedt]] |first2= [[ragnar löfstedt|ragnar]] |last3= sjöstedt |first3= gunnar|publisher=[[earthscan]]|year=2001|isbn= 978-1-85383-537-7|accessdate=31 december 2009}}</ref> lithuania agreed to close the plant as part of its accession agreement to the [[european union]].
unit 1 was closed in december 2004.

the remaining unit 2 which counted for 25%<!--deutcshe welle says 40%: ...and accounts for about 40 percent of the countrys overall production capacity.--> of lithuanias electricity generating capacity and supplied about 70% of lithuanias electrical demand,<ref name=dw311209a>{{cite news | title = lithuania shuts down last reactor | url = http://www.dw-world.de/dw/article/0,,5074094,00.html

| publisher = [[deutsche welle]] | author = houlton, susan | date = 31 december 2009 | accessdate=31 december 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite conference |title=electricity market in the baltic countries | url= http://events.le.lt/uploads/file/20060126/electricity%20markets%20in%20balticstates_jank.ppt

| author = jankauskas, vidmantas | conference = development of electricity markets and security of supply in the baltic sea region | location = [[vilnius]] | publisher=[[lietuvos energija]] | format = ppt | date= 26 january 2006 | accessdate= 19 april 2008}}</ref> was closed on december 31, 2009.
proposals have been made to construct a new nuclear power plant at the same site.
Erro:507
1.]]  the ignalina nuclear power plant contained two [[rbmk]]-1500 [[water-cooled]] [[graphite]]-[[neutron moderator|moderated]] channel-type power [[nuclear reactor|reactors]].

the soviet-designed rbmk-1500 reactor was originally the most powerful reactor in the world with an electrical power capacity of 1,500 [[watt|megawatt]]s (mw) and thermal power capacity of 4,800 mw, but this distinction was later superseded by other nuclear reactors elsewhere.{{citation
needed|date=october 2014}} after the [[chernobyl disaster]] of april 1986 the reactor was de-rated to 1,360 mw.
these are of a similar type of reactor (rbmk-1000) as at the [[chernobyl nuclear power plant|chernobyl power plant]], hence the european unions insistence on closing them.{{citation
needed|date=september 2011}} each unit of the power plant was equipped with two k-750-65/3000 turbines with 800 mw generators.<ref

name=td3>{{cite web|url=http://www.iae.lt/en/about-us/history/technical-data/?page=3|title=ignalina nuclear power plant: technical data|accessdate=2015-12-11}}</ref>  in december 1983, when ignalina unit 1 came online, a design flaw of the [[rbmk]] was noticed for the first time.
the graphite moderated tips on the control rods, which partially caused the chernobyl accident, were entered into the reactor.
in this case the control rods did not get stuck, and could get down to the bottom of the reactor.
the [[boron]] in the control rods stopped the nuclear reaction.
other nuclear organizations and rbmk plants were informed of the problem, but it was not addressed until after the accident at chernobyl.<ref
name=i2>{{cite web|url=http://www-pub.iaea.org/mtcd/publications/pdf/pub913e_web.pdf

|publisher=[[international atomic energy agency]] (iaea)|year=1992|pages=23, 25, 125, 129 (pdf page numbering)|title=insag-7 -the chernobyl accident: updating of insag-1|accessdate=2011-04-03}}</ref> the subsequent modifications were tested at ignalina during 1987 and 1988.<ref
name=i2/>  ==history== preparations for the construction began in 1974.
field work began four years later.
unit 1 came online in december 1983, and was closed on december 31, 2004.
unit 2 came online in august 1987 and was closed on december 31, 2009 at 23:00 [[eastern european time|eet]] (21:00 [[coordinated universal time|utc]]).<ref

name=nea>{{cite book |title= nuclear legislation in central and eastern europe and the nis: 2003 overview |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=nhsclfb64ewc&pg=pa116 |page= 116 |publisher=[[oecd]] |year=2004 |isbn= 978-92-64-01542-5 |accessdate=31 december 2009 |author= nuclear energy agency, organisation for economic co-operation and development.}}</ref><ref
name=bbc>{{cite news | title = lithuania to shut its only nuclear power station | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/8435628.stm

| publisher = bbc news | date = 31 december 2009 |accessdate=31 december 2009}}</ref><ref name=businessweek>{{cite news | title =lithuania shuts down soviet-built nuclear reactor | url = http://www.businessweek.com/ap/financialnews/d9cucpio0.htm

| publisher = [[bloomberg l.p.|bloomberg]]| author = dapkus, liudas | work = [[businessweek]]| date = 31 december 2009 |accessdate=31 december 2009}}</ref><ref name=reuters311209a>{{cite news | title = lithuania to shut soviet-era nuclear plant | url = http://uk.reuters.com/article/iduklde5bu0ic20091231?sp=true | publisher = reuters| author = adomaitis, nerijus | date = 31 december 2009 |accessdate=31 december 2009}}</ref>  originally, unit 2 was scheduled for launch in 1986, but its commissioning was postponed for a year because of the [[chernobyl accident]].
the construction of unit 3 started in 1985, but was suspended in 1988 and its demolition began in 1989.
its dismantling was completed in 2008.<ref
name=wnn160908> {{cite news  | url= http://www.world-nuclear-news.org/it-dismantling_of_unfinished_ignalina_unit_completed-1609085.html

| title= dismantling of unfinished ignalina unit completed  | date= 2008-09-16  | work= world nuclear news  | accessdate= 2011-09-09}} </ref>  construction of the unit 4 never started because of the public backlash against nuclear power following the chernobyl disaster.{{citation
